Los Angeles, CA 7/12/2012 I have loved this place eve since I was a kid. Where else do you get to eat, drink and watch knights joist? They really try to cater to the whole experience. First you can easily get discount tickets online so do a quick Google search before you buy. Second get the group photo with costumes despite the cost. Also plan on coming early so you can tour the grounds and see all the really cool stuff (like the dungeon of terror).
The food is actually good and there is enough to get the job done if you eat everything (or steal off your lady's plate hehe). The show is top notch. A quick warning it can be scary for a young child. If you have an event and tell them about it early they will read it off as an announcement.
I would definitely go back anytime.

Elaine N.
Westminster, CA 7/9/2012 I guess you can say after becoming obsessed with Game of Thrones, I had to make sure I live it as if I were a real Lady -- having dinner served to me by wenches, being called "my Lady," and greeted by bows from knights and squires.
I remember attending the dinner and tournament as a young lady, but did not have much recollection of it... I just remember watching knights on their horses, riding back and forth. Now that I am much older, I can fully appreciate the beauty of winning a game of jousting to honor their respective land.
The food was definitely more delicious than what I remembered... I read somewhere on Yelp that they changed the menu and made it better.
The wench brought out some Dragon soup (aka tomato soup), which was warm, but not too hot that would burn your mouth... after all, you have to eat all these without utensils, including the soup! It was a bit bland and not dense enough for me. It was like drinking tomato soup. The garlic bread, however, was very warm and tasted like it just came out from a baker's iron stove. Next came the baby dragons, which tasted just like chicken. They were very moist, and the skin had great seasoning (wished I brought my own condiments to make it better though). The dragon ribs were my favorite, although I should warn you to not expect much... After all, you are paying more for the show, not the meal.
The show was alright. The only thing I did not like was that it had no interesting plot, but I loved the performances that the knights and their squires delivered. Most of the jousting and battling looked very real. Weapons were clashed against each other, sparks were made, and some even broke.
There were some boring scenes, such as parts where horses just walked around the stage as if they were doing something clever. The "English" accents from the Lord and the King was horrible. I could not understand half of the things they were saying. Luckily for them, the knights made up for their lack of duty.
Overall I would give this a 3.5. I also got the tickets when they were on sale for about 45% off, while they were promoting their new show. I would definitely not pay the full admission price for this though... It's fun, but I am pretty sure I can do more with $50 (per person!) than watch a bunch of men dressed as knights and wave their sticks around. For $30, it is a steal! Feasting like kings in a crowded city in front of a king and the princess, while watching knights and their squires battle to the death.

Ok, this place is silly and fun. Everything is fake, so expect it. It's fun if you can play make believe. If you have younger ones along for the evening, it becomes that much more fun.
You don't really get to choose your dinner. No, the king has chosen. Bill of fare, tomato bisque, half roasted chicken, spare rib, herb potato wedges, apple pastry, Pepsi. Yes, the king has chosen. It's descent and messy. Enjoy!

Orange, CA 6/5/2012 1 Check-in Here I was on the fence between a 3 star and 4 star review here but I ultimately had so much fun, I couldn't go with anything less than 4. I will be blunt though...Medieval Times is nachos with extra cheese. From the paper crowns you wear to the fake jousting where the actors throw themselves off the horses about 5 minutes after they actually get hit, but it's all so entertaining you can't help but cheer along. My friend and I even gave our knight a fake name just so we could yell for him when it was his turn (he came in second by the way. A silver medal if I've ever seen one). The guy that was the host was incredibly entertaining too.
I'd always heard the food was mediocre but other than the soup (which was pretty bland), it was actually quite good and you get A LOT of it. Think Medieval Claim Jumper. We went to an earlier show too so parking was plentiful but it looks like if you went to a later show on a weekend, it wouldn't be quite as easy. We got there pretty early too but there's a full bar and nice courtyard area to sit in while you wait.
I think this is something everyone should go to at least once in their lives. I was lucky enough to have free tickets. I'm not sure if my review would be the same if I'd shelled out the $50 - $60 for the whole thing. But definitely a fun and different excursion for a weekend with a meal that might actually leave you with leftovers. Oh and you might have to pay $10 for a margarita but they are yummy and you get to keep the glass (as long as you aren't absentminded like me and forget it there).
Are you ready to get Medieval?

Hacienda Heights, CA 5/6/2012 4 photos 1 Check-in Here Free entry for Moms on Mother's day weekend!
---
Hubby has always wanted to see this and after a recent visit to Pirate's Adventure, we decided to try Medieval Times too. It helped that they were doing a Spring Break promo during March and April and it was only $30 for "students". You need a student ID to qualify per their website but they didn't really check.
Eh. It's me not you, Medieval Times. I don't like going to the zoo, aquariums, or anywhere where animals are not in their natural habitats. I also don't like PETA but I digress. I should have known that I would not enjoy being here because of the horses. I wish they didn't show them off in those glass cases. It looked really uncomfortable and took away from my enjoyment of the show.
The food was surprisingly okay -- if you don't come with high expectations. After reading all the Yelp reviews, I came in not expecting much from their food. I decided to get the vegetarian option. Who said you can't eat with utensils here? The veggie option comes with a plastic knife and fork LOL!
Tomato bisque soup -- either I was just hungry or it was really good. I liked it and I don't usually like tomato.
Focaccia bread -- too soft, not sure if that was a good or bad thing. It was just okay.
Hummus and pita -- good, pretty standard
Skewer of veggies -- I liked it
Stuffed pepper -- definitely the highlight of my meal. I wasn't sure how to go about eating it. Thankfully, I had a fork! I was just gonna pick it up but it was going to be too messy with the rice. It was a flavorful combination!
Herb-basted potato - pretty average
Pro-tip: If you're dining with a non-vegetarian, the server will offer them an extra rib.
Hubby really liked it so he'll be writing his 4-star review.

Irvine, CA 4/29/2012 1 Check-in Here My silly girl-friends took me here for my birthday this year and we had a blast!!! We know it's for little kids, but if you just let go of all your reservations and go with the flow, you'll have a lot of fun! We were team yellow/red-striped and our knight was the BEST... he was so into it and always looked at us whenever he was up for a fight. Some of the other knights didn't seem as "committed" to their role as our knight! Our little squire was pretty darn cute too.
The fight scenes are exciting and intense even though they're so obviously fake and rehearsed. We screamed at the top of our lungs and took a gazillion pictures. The food wasn't bad either!! Much better than I expected, and they give you tons of food. We started off with focaccia bread. Then came the tomato bisque (it was watery and not creamy like a true tomato bisque should be). The entree is where it's at though... they gave us huge pieces of (surprisingly) tender rotisserie chicken (which they called a dragon leg), and some BBQed ribs. YUM!! You finish off with an apple pie that's similar to the McDonald's apple pie pockets.
All in all a great experience... my friends were so creative to take me here, and they knew I'm just silly enough to love it!

Encino, CA 4/23/2012 1 Check-in Here My dad took me to the Medieval Times in Dallas back when I was 9 or 10 and I remember LOVING it. So, at 24, I decided to give it another go. I truly wish I hadn't.
PROS (what few there were) -Museum of torture was interesting (albeit horrifying) -Some of the cheesy acting was so terrible that it was actually amusing -Apple pie pastry was decent
CONS -Yucky meal -Overpriced drinks ($15 for a slushie?) -Truly upsetting animal cruelty exhibited. They allow you to look into the horse stalls (where the horses LIVE) while you are waiting for the show to begin, and I noticed immediately that the horses were tied to the walls in their stall with a 10 inch tether; that didn't even give them enough room to turn around or walk two steps! Horses looked beaten down and terribly sad. I've been around animals much of my life and I have never seen animals looking this beaten up. Many had wounds and looked ill. Once the show started it got far worse. They were forced to do unnatural tricks and were moved along with shark spurs and whips. One horse's tongue was completely hanging out of his mouth the whole show...another kept running the wrong way and the rider got violent with him. I was so upset I was almost in tears the whole show.
Bottom line ---- kids seem to enjoy this show, but I wouldn't recommend ever bringing anyone (even your kid) unless they get their act together.

Redondo Beach, CA 4/19/2012 4 photos 1 Check-in Here Bow your head, kiss my hand ... and only refer to me as "My-Lady". (well, that's what happened to me ... and I loved it)
Medieval Times Dinner&Tournament was a great.
We arrived an hour early, as the seating is general admission and assigned on a first come first served basis. Seating assignments in hand, we perused the area designated to "hang" where we shopped, took pictures and grabbed drinks from the full bar.
The food? Good. Tomato soup, warm pita style bread, a pork rib, half of a roasted chicken, potato skins and a warm flaky crusted apple dessert. Soda, Iced tea and coffee to wet your whistle. Yes, the food is served without utensils in metal ol' skooled tableware - ya know - just like at your house (wink).
There didn't appear to be a bad seat in the house. Arriving 20-30 minutes prior to the performance start time, would be sufficient. As opposed to their suggested 1 full hour, advanced arrival.
The performance was intriguing, the camaraderie was refreshing, the horse showmanship was captivating.

Los Angeles, CA 2/13/2012 It's been about 20 years since I've been here to the Medieval Times Dinner&Tournament show. There is still the same excitement and energy that makes for a very fun evening! $50 an adult - totally worth the price!
The night started off with doing a first check in at the front, where they take your name and tickets. The service people tell you to take your place in line at ANOTHER check in area (why twice?) where they give you color tickets of where you should sit. (NOTE: Go early so you can reserve seats towards the front of the action!). You walk past the second check in and they give you matching crowns (one of six colors) and have you take photos with the Medieval characters (each color section had their own character, so they knew where to find you later to sell you photos - $20 for the first photo, $10 for the second).
The dinner show is about 2 hours long and it is filled packed with entertainment and a great time! The three main actors (Lord Knight, King, and Princess) play a cheesy role, which totally entertains the crowds! My favorite was the Lord Knight, because he totally knew how to engage the audience and make everyone laugh spontaneously. We were seated in the Red Knight section and he came in 2nd place in the battle of the knights! Super exciting.
Dinner consisted of a tomato bisque soup, fresh flat bread, a 1/2 roasted chicken, 2 wedges of potato fries, one beef rib, two cups of your beverage choice, and a sweet dessert at the end. The food was good picnic food, and the fun thing is that you get to eat with your hands. REMEMBER TO BRING SANITIZER as they don't provide it for you. Our waitress was very very hard working and patient with all the requests that the guests made of her! (Sorry, I don't remember your name, 2/12/12 Red Section Row 5).
Throughout the entire 2 hour experience, you are provided with action packed entertainment. There are 8 knights and each of them has their cheering section of the auditorium. Each of the knights totally work hard at providing real-life (well, almost) action fighting with 5+ different types of weapons. These guys not only ride horses very well, but they also do full swings on their opponents while fighting. Yes, the fighting is very rehearsed, but the blows that they serve each other are at full force and the sparks from the metal swords / sheilds / chains fly everywhere. These guys work hard for their money, so I hope they are paid well to do what they do! Exciting! What a great time!
Don't forget to visit the huge gift shop before or after the show. Buying a 1' flag to cheer your knight on (color coordinated, of course) is a MUST at $5 each! You can also get knight costumes, princess gears, mugs, pewter figurines, and even real life metal sword$). Fun to shop here!
My only negative about this experience was the parking. The afternoon show is at 3:00 and ends after 5:00. This means that if you get there ahead of time to get a good seat, there is NO parking in the lot. Once the show gets out, there is a RUSH to get out of the lot and the next shift of cars rush in to get a parking stall. Dangerous for kids and older people - so be careful!
Food Grade: B. Entertainment Grade: A-. Service Grade: A- Parking situation Grade: C Overall impression Grade: B+
